newsitem.title: DENMARK: Legal problems could delay Danish Maastricht case.
newsitem.headline: Legal problems could delay Danish Maastricht case.

text.p: Procedural delays could put back the planned May start of a High Court suit by 10 Danes challenging the legality of Denmark's European Union (EU) membership, a government lawyer said on Tuesday.

"The date for the final submission of the group's deposition has been postponed until March 6 from February 28. I do not know if this will affect the timing of the start of the case," state defence lawyer Karsten Hagen-Soerensen told Reuters.
He said technical problems on the plantiffs' side caused the extension of the deadline.
In November the group, which calls itself the Constitution Committee, suffered a setback when court authorities turned down its request to have confidential government documents brought in evidence.

The rebuff followed a preliminary High Court hearing to set the boundaries for a legal challenge by the non-partisan Constitution Committee which claims that since joining the EU in 1973 Denmark has ceded national authority to European institutions in breach of its own constitution.
A second request for access to official documents is still being studied by the authorities and a ruling is expected next month.
The Constitution Committee is to open separate legal proceedings next month, seeking leave to appeal to the Supreme Court against the November document ruling.
Legal experts see the ban on bringing classified state documents as evidence as limiting the scope of the trial and strengthening the government's chances of victory.
Defeat could oblige Denmark to renegotiate its EU treaties from scratch or to try to amend the constitution, a complex operation requiring a general election and a referendum.
Danes, traditionally cool toward European integration, rejected the Maastricht Treaty outright in a 1992 referendum.

Voters grudgingly approved the treaty the following year on condition that Denmark opt out of economic and monetary union and joint defence, policing and citizenship arrangements. --Chris Follett, Copenhagen newsroom +45-33969652
